questions.text: A 21-year-old college student presents with feelings of anxiety. She explains that since starting college, she has become increasingly insecure about her weight, particularly after gaining a few kgs. To cope with the stress of her coursework and social pressures, she often binge-eats high-calorie snacks during late-night study sessions. After these episodes, she feels intense guilt and frequently induces vomiting to avoid weight gain. On physical examination, her BMI is measured at 16.5 kg/m and her heart rate is 70 beats per minute. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Anorexia Nervosa - Clinical Features:

Restriction of Energy Intake
  • Low body weight (Most characteristic feature)
  • BMI <18.5kg/m² in adults
  • BMI-for-age under 5th percentile in children/adolescents

Intense Fear of Weight Gain
  • Persistent fear of gaining weight or becoming obese

Body Image Distortion
  • Undue influence of body weight/shape on self-evaluation
  • Inaccurate perception of being normal or overweight

Amenorrhea
  • Previously required but no longer necessary for diagnosis in DSM-5 or ICD-11

Peculiar Food Behaviors
  • Hiding food
  • Disposing of food in napkins
  • Rearranging food on plate
  • Collecting recipes and cooking for others

Delayed sexual development
  • Have poor sexual adjustment
  • Adults may have decreased interest in sex.

Gender prevalence
  • More common in females than males

Anorexia Nervosa - Medical Complications

Vital signs

Bradycardia, hypotension, hypothermia, poikilothermia

General

Muscle atrophy, loss of body fat

Central nervous system

Generalized brain atrophy with enlarged ventricles

Cardiovascular

Peripheral (starvation) edema, superior mesenteric artery syndrome

Hematologic

Anemia of starvation, leukopenia

Gastrointestinal

Decreased intestinal lipase and lactase

Metabolic

Hypercholesterolemia, nonsymptomatic hypoglycemia, elevated liver enzymes, decreased bone mineral density

Endocrine

Decrease: LH, FSH, Estrogen or Testosterone, T3, T4

Increase: Reverse T3, Cortisol, GH, prolactin

Normal: TSH

questions.text: A 22-year-old female who is an aspiring model presents with complaints of gastrointestinal discomfort and concerns about her weight. Since beginning her modeling career, she has become increasingly anxious about her body image, feeling pressure to maintain a slim figure to secure modeling opportunities. Recently, she has also started binge eating high-calorie foods during stressful periods, followed by feelings of guilt. To counteract this, she regularly uses over-the-counter laxatives, believing they help her feel thinner. Her BMI is measured at 17 kg/m² and her heart rate is 70 beats per minute. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Type of Anorexia Nervosa

Characteristics

Binge-Eating/Purging type
  • Recurring purging behaviors (e.g., laxative, diuretic abuse, self-induced vomiting)
  • Episodes of binge eating
  • Occurs at least once a week over the last 3 months

Restricting type
  • Primary behaviors include dieting, fasting, and/or excessive exercise
  • No recurring purging behaviors or binge eating over the last 3 months

questions.text: A 19-year-old female presents with significant anxiety about gaining weight. She has a BMI of 16 kg/m² and she engages in excessive exercise. During the consultation, she reports feeling isolated from her friends and family, who are worried about her health. What is the most appropriate next best step for this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Bupropion for anxiety and weight gain

options.label: D
options.text: Nutritional counseling with a focus on portion control

questions.correct_answer: B. Supervised feeding with individual psychotherapy
questions.explanation:
Management Type

Details

Non-Pharmacological Management

Individual Psychotherapy

Focus on behavior modification and improving body image.

Supervised Feeding

Structured meal plans in a monitored setting to ensure nutritional intake.

Nutritional Rehabilitation

Educating patients about nutrition and healthy eating patterns.

Counseling to address maladaptive thoughts and attitudes toward food and body image.

Family Support

Involvement of family members to provide emotional support and understanding.

Treat Life-Threatening Complications

Address any medical complications (e.g., electrolyte imbalances, dehydration) as necessary.

Pharmacological Treatment

SSRIs

Can be prescribed to help induce weight gain and manage underlying anxiety or depression.

Olanzapine

May be considered if there is no adequate response to psychotherapy or SSRIs.

Bupropion (Option A)

Contraindicated in patients with anorexia or bulimia due to the increased risk of seizures.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presents to the hospital with lethargy and giddiness. He has a history of being bullied at school due to his physical appearance, which led him to become increasingly interested in various forms of exercise. Over the past three months, he has lost 24 kilograms due to exercise. An ECG performed upon admission is shown below. He appears cachectic and pale. He is assessed by a dietitian and started on nutritional supplements. Two days later, the patient exhibits involuntary muscle contractions, followed by periods of unresponsiveness and confusion. Which electrolyte abnormality would most likely be seen in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Category

Details

Risk Factors
  • Severe malnutrition (e.g., anorexia nervosa, prolonged fasting)
  • Patients who have experienced significant weight loss or are undergoing aggressive refeeding

Metabolic Changes (Option B, C)

Increased insulin levels lead to shifts in electrolytes, particularly:

  • Decreased phosphate (PO4³⁻): Essential for energy production and cellular function. Most common electrolyte abnormality seen in this condition; it is accompanied by prolonged QT interval and bradycardia.
  • Decreased potassium (K⁺): Important for cardiac and muscular function.
  • Decreased magnesium (Mg²⁺): Critical for many biochemical reactions and muscle function.

Clinical Complications
  • Cardiac complications: Arrhythmias due to electrolyte imbalances.
  • Rhabdomyolysis: Muscle breakdown caused by electrolyte disturbances and increased workload.
  • Seizures: Can occur due to severe electrolyte imbalances.

Management

To prevent refeeding syndrome, it is crucial to:

  • Start feeding at a reduced caloric rate and gradually increase.
  • Monitor electrolytes closely, particularly phosphate, potassium, and magnesium.
  • Provide thiamine supplementation before correcting glucose levels.

questions.text: A 22-year-old female medical student presents with a preoccupation with her body image that has persisted since age 13. She describes engaging in constant mirror checking and spending significant time scrutinizing her reflection. However, she acknowledges that her friends and family do not notice any flaws in her appearance and often compliment her. She reports episodes of binge eating followed by engaging in excessive exercise twice a week, for the past 6 months. She expresses significant emotional distress, stating, “I feel like I can’t stop myself from overeating, and then I panic about gaining weight”. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Binge Eating Episodes
  • Recurring episodes of binge eating, occurring at least weekly for the last 3 months.

Compensatory Behaviors
  • Purging behaviors (self-induced vomiting, laxative abuse, diuretics), excessive exercise, fasting.

BMI
  • Often normal or slightly overweight (compared to anorexia nervosa).

Gender prevalence

  • More common in females than males

Physical Signs
  • Parotid gland hypertrophy (may see increased serum amylase)
  • Enamel erosion (from vomiting)
  • Mallory-Weiss syndrome (esophageal tears)

These signs appear due to repeated purging.

Electrolyte Disturbances
  • Commonly hypokalemia and hypochloremia.

Metabolic Changes
  • Metabolic alkalosis due to vomiting.

Physical Findings
  • Dorsal hand calluses from induced vomiting (Russell sign).

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with symptoms of anxiety that have persisted for the past six months. She is seeking medication to help manage her symptoms. Her medical history is unremarkable; she is non-diabetic, non-hypertensive, and has no family history of medical illnesses except for a recent history of bulimia nervosa. Given her background, which of the following medications would pose the highest risk of side effects if prescribed?

A 32-year-old woman with a BMI of 32 kg/m² reports frequent episodes of overeating, feeling disgusted afterwards, and eating even when not hungry. She denies compensatory behaviors like vomiting. What is the most appropriate first-line treatment?
questions.explanation:
Comorbid Conditions

Additional Associations

Mood disorders

Unstable weight (frequent weight cycling)

Anxiety disorders

Insomnia

Substance use disorders

Early menarche

Obesity (nearly half)

Chronic pain in neck, shoulders, or back

Risk of obesity-related issues

Metabolic disorders

Medication

Effectiveness

Lisdexamfetamine (Option A)

Effective for weight loss and reducing binges

Antidepressants

Improve binge episodes but don't cause sustained weight loss

Topiramate & Zonisamide (Option D)

Moderate weight loss and reduced binge episodes

Combined CBT + Medication

More effective for weight loss than medication or CBT alone

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician by his parents due to concerns about his eating habits. They report that he has a limited variety of foods he is willing to eat and has lost interest in mealtime, often refusing to eat altogether. The boy does not express any fear of weight gain and has not experienced significant weight loss. Which of the following characteristics most likely indicates that he is suffering from Avoidant Restrictive Food Intake Disorder (ARFID)?

options.label: A
options.text: Intense fear of gaining weight leading to severe caloric restriction

options.label: B
options.text: Disturbance in eating patterns due to sensory sensitivities or aversive reactions to food

options.label: C
options.text: Compulsive exercise to maintain a specific body weight

options.label: D
options.text: Engagement in binge-eating episodes followed by purging behavior

questions.correct_answer: B. Disturbance in eating patterns due to sensory sensitivities or aversive reactions to food
questions.explanation:
Feature

Description

Eating Patterns

Symptoms arise from sensory sensitivities, lack of interest, or aversive reactions to certain foods, not body image concerns.

Demographics

Patients are generally younger with less weight loss before treatment; often depend on enteral nutrition and may have longer hospital stays.

Comorbidities

Overlap with other eating disorders, especially in adolescents; some develop traditional eating disorder psychopathology alongside ARFID symptoms.

Treatment

Description

Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT)

Incorporates systematic desensitization and cognitive restructuring, showing improvement in food acceptance and reduced anxiety related to eating.

Family-Based Therapy

Involves family members in treatment, aiding in maintaining progress at home.

Pharmacological Treatments

Some medications are being researched to alleviate associated anxiety or comorbid conditions.

questions.text: Which of the following best differentiates night-eating syndrome from sleep-related eating disorder?

options.label: A
options.text: Higher prevalence of comorbid bulimia nervosa and binge-eating disorder

options.label: B
options.text: Consumption of non-edible foods or substances during eating episodes

options.label: C
options.text: Lack of concern about body image or weight

options.label: D
options.text: Increased risk of developing obesity and metabolic syndrome

questions.correct_answer: B. Consumption of non-edible foods or substances during eating episodes
questions.explanation:
Feature

Night-Eating Syndrome (NES)

Sleep-Related Eating Disorder (SRED)

Awareness during episodes

Preserved (fully awake and aware)

Absent or impaired (amnesia common)

Time of eating

Late evening or during night awakenings

During sleep, often within parasomnia episodes

Control over eating

Volitional

Involuntary

Items consumed

Normal food

Non-edible or dangerous items often consumed

Association with other EDs

May coexist with BED or depression

May be comorbid with sleep disorders
